title.narrative: POLICIES, PLANS AND BUDGETS FOR CHILDREN

description.narrative: Government at central and sub-national levels has strengthened capacity to improve equity focus and priorities children in policies, plans, and budgets, which contributes to Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children, Economic And Social Policy General, Public Finance And Local Governance, Social Protection. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Child poverty in all its forms is reduced through quality, evidence-based policies, programmes and budgets for all children, especially the most marginalized, at national and subnational levels

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Government at central and sub-national levels has strengthened capacity to improve equity focus and priorities children in policies, plans, and budgets

description.narrative: A high-level political dialogue was established with the Parliament to present key findings of the 2018 Budget Briefs and Nutrition Public Expenditure Review, which provoked discussions about critical budgeting challenges and addressing them during the budget scrutinization process. Moreover, given the low level of budget spending on child nutrition by local governments, MPs discussed and suggested that the central government should provide additional funding for nutrition. The enabling environment for child-focused budgeting is expected to benefit from the new National Decentralization Policy, which was finalized with UNICEF support and will be submitted to Cabinet by early 2020. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:16/01/2020

title.narrative: Evidence generated on budgets and their linkages to child outcomes to improve budget allocations/expenditure for children

baseline.value: Intermediate (2) UNICEF has generated evidence to support budget allocation/ expenditure, but advocacy has not yet demonstrated improved budget allocation/ expenditures

target.value: 2021:Advanced (3) UNICEF generated evidence and advocacy has led to improved budget allocation/ expenditure

title.narrative: Evidence generated on budgets and their linkages to child outcomes to improve budget allocations/expenditure for children

baseline.value: Intermediate (2) UNICEF has generated evidence to support budget allocation/ expenditure, but advocacy has not yet demonstrated improved budget allocation/ expenditures

target.value: 2021:Advanced (3) UNICEF generated evidence and advocacy has led to improved budget allocation/ expenditure

actual.value: 2019:Disaggregated data at central and local government levels was collected to support the budget analyses.

title.narrative: (NOT VALID after Dec 31 2017) National budgetary frameworks that address child poverty and disparities

baseline.value: Issues of adequacy, effectiveness, efficiency and equity affecting public social sector spending, with sub-national allocation formulas largely ineffective in addressing disparities.

target.value: 2021:Allocations to child-focused areas increased in national and sub-national budget, quality of spending enhanced, and allocation formulas for key social sectors revised for increased equity focus.

actual.value: 2019:A set of policy proposals on enhancing the inter-governmental fiscal transfer formulas has been pending for Cabinet approval since 2015.

title.narrative: National budgetary frameworks that address child poverty and disparities

baseline.value: Issues of adequacy, effectiveness, efficiency and equity affecting public social sector spending, with sub-national allocation formulas largely ineffective in addressing disparities.

target.value: 2021:Allocations to child-focused areas increased in national and sub-national budget, quality of spending enhanced, and allocation formulas for key social sectors revised for increased equity focus.

actual.value: 2019:A set of policy proposals on enhancing the inter-governmental fiscal transfer formulas has been pending for Cabinet approval since 2015.

title.narrative: (NOT VALID after Dec 31 2017) Information and reports on child-focused public expenditures (by sector and sub-sector) is available by governments; sectors are health, nutrition, child protection, social protection, WASH and education

baseline.value: Mainland: limited and inconsistent analysis available. Zanzibar: not publicly available.

target.value: 2021:Information and reports are regularly produced, and made publicly available, on public spending for all sectors relevant to child wellbeing.

actual.value:
2019:Context-specific CPEM discontinued due to lack of data and relevance.
7 Budget Briefs launched and on MOFP website

title.narrative: Extent to which the national decentralization legal and policy framework reflects equity and child rights considerations

baseline.value: Weak (Score 1) Ad hoc references to poor and/or disadvantaged children as beneficiaries of decentralization reform

target.value: 2021:Established (Score 3) Poor and/or disadvantaged children are consistently referenced as beneficiaries in laws and/or other legal instruments that formally establish decentralization framework.

actual.value: 2019:A new National Decentralization Policy was developed with a technical support of UNICEF. The Cabinet paper for approval of the policy is in place.
